messages.content: <QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahetou</WORD> instead of <WORD>aheai</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ahetou</WORD> and <WORD>aheai</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ahetou</WORD> <DEFINITION>1. to approach (continuation of aheai), 2. to not be afraid of approaching (a relative, a hostile person)</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>aheai</WORD> <DEFINITION>to approach (beginning of a process)</DEFINITION>.

Examples with <WORD>ahetou</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>pei yoka ha a ahetou tëhë a husi koikoimoma</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>he whistled when he was near the entrance (of the south of the Orinoco)</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>pë yesi kë iha a ahetou</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>he is not afraid to approach his mother-in-law</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>aheai</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>thë aheai</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>that is approaching</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>aheai</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahetou</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>aheai</WORD> and <WORD>ahetou</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>aheai</WORD> <DEFINITION>to approach (beginning of a process)</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ahetou</WORD> <DEFINITION>1. to approach (continuation of aheai), 2. to not be afraid of approaching (a relative, a hostile person)</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>aheai</WORD> when you want to express to approach (beginning of a process). Use <WORD>ahetou</WORD> when you want to express 1.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>aheai</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>thë aheai</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>that is approaching</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ya aheai</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>I am approaching</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>ahetou</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>pei yoka ha a ahetou tëhë a husi koikoimoma</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>he whistled when he was near the entrance (of the south of the Orinoco)</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>iku</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahete</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>iku</WORD> and <WORD>ahete</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>iku</WORD> <DEFINITION>perfective aspect marker for intransitive verbs</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ahete</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be close</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>iku</WORD> when you want to express perfective aspect marker for intransitive verbs. Use <WORD>ahete</WORD> when you want to express to be close.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>iku</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>a ta përiiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>lie down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>a ta ikuiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>come closer</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>ahete</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>when I was close I sat down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>iku</WORD> instead of <WORD>ikiyo</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>iku</WORD> and <WORD>ikiyo</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>iku</WORD> is a <POS>Suffix</POS> and <DEFINITION>perfective aspect marker for intransitive verbs</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ikiyo</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Intransitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to go</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>iku</WORD> when you want to express perfective aspect marker for intransitive verbs. Use <WORD>ikiyo</WORD> when you want to express to go.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>iku</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>a ta përiiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>lie down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>a ta ikuiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>come closer</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>ikiyo</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>a ta roikiyo</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>sit here</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>iku</WORD> instead of <WORD>ke</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>iku</WORD> and <WORD>ke</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>iku</WORD> <DEFINITION>perfective aspect marker for intransitive verbs</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ke</WORD> <DEFINITION>perfective aspect marker</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>iku</WORD> when you want to express perfective aspect marker for intransitive verbs. Use <WORD>ke</WORD> when you want to express perfective aspect marker.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>iku</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>a ta përiiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>lie down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>a ta ikuiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>come closer</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>ke</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>a ta roiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>sit down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahete</WORD> instead of <WORD>iku</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ahete</WORD> and <WORD>iku</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ahete</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be close</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>iku</WORD> <DEFINITION>perfective aspect marker for intransitive verbs</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ahete</WORD> when you want to express to be close. Use <WORD>iku</WORD> when you want to express perfective aspect marker for intransitive verbs.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>ahete</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>when I was close I sat down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ira kë a wãri ahetetou totihio tëhë, a mori niyãõ tëhë, ikãri a shëi shoaoma</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>at the moment the jaguar was close to him, at the moment it was going to jump, he hit it with all his might</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>iku</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>a ta përiiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>lie down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahete</WORD> instead of <WORD>owe</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ahete</WORD> and <WORD>owë</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ahete</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be close</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>owë</WORD> <DEFINITION>to enumerate, to count using the fingers</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ahete</WORD> when you want to express to be close. Use <WORD>owë</WORD> when you want to express to enumerate, to count using the fingers.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>ahete</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>when I was close I sat down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ira kë a wãri ahetetou totihio tëhë, a mori niyãõ tëhë, ikãri a shëi shoaoma</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>at the moment the jaguar was close to him, at the moment it was going to jump, he hit it with all his might</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>owë</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>imiki ta owëiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>count with your fingers</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahete</WORD> instead of <WORD>pesheku</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ahete</WORD> and <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ahete</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be close</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be near</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ahete</WORD> when you want to express to be close. Use <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> when you want to express to be near.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahete</WORD> instead of <WORD>tikuku</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ahete</WORD> and <WORD>tikuku</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ahete</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be close</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>tikuku</WORD> <DEFINITION>stoke</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ahete</WORD> when you want to express to be close. Use <WORD>tikuku</WORD> when you want to express stoke.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>ahete</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>when I was close I sat down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ira kë a wãri ahetetou totihio tëhë, a mori niyãõ tëhë, ikãri a shëi shoaoma</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>at the moment the jaguar was close to him, at the moment it was going to jump, he hit it with all his might</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>tikuku</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ira thë hore hãimai ma kui, ira a hore tikukuprou tëhë, thoku ta thaprahe</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>while I keep the jaguar away (with my supernatural powers), while it stays at a respectful distance, (you can) take down the hammocks and leave</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahete</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahe</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ahete</WORD> and <WORD>ahe</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ahete</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be close</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ahe</WORD> <DEFINITION>my wife, with whom I make love</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ahete</WORD> when you want to express to be close. Use <WORD>ahe</WORD> when you want to express my wife, with whom I make love.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>owe</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahete</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>owë</WORD> and <WORD>ahete</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>owë</WORD> <DEFINITION>to enumerate, to count using the fingers</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ahete</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be close</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>owë</WORD> when you want to express to enumerate, to count using the fingers. Use <WORD>ahete</WORD> when you want to express to be close.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>owë</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>imiki ta owëiku</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>count with your fingers</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>fimiki owëo</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>to enumerate, to count using the fingers</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>ahete</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>when I was close I sat down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>pesheku</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahete</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> and <WORD>ahete</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be near</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ahete</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be close</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> when you want to express to be near. Use <WORD>ahete</WORD> when you want to express to be close.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>pesheku</WORD> instead of <WORD>peye</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> and <WORD>pëyë</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Intransitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to be near</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>pëyë</WORD> is a <POS>Noun</POS> and <DEFINITION>clearing, field</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> when you want to express to be near. Use <WORD>pëyë</WORD> when you want to express clearing, field.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>pesheku</WORD> instead of <WORD>poushokuwe</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> and <WORD>poushokuwë</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be near</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>poushokuwë</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be near</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> when you want to express to be near. Use <WORD>poushokuwë</WORD> when you want to express to be near.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>pesheku</WORD> instead of <WORD>peishoki</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> and <WORD>pëishoki</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be near</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>pëishoki</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be near</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> when you want to express to be near. Use <WORD>pëishoki</WORD> when you want to express to be near.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>pesheku</WORD> instead of <WORD>poushoku</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> and <WORD>poushoku</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be near</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>poushoku</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be near</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>pëshëku</WORD> when you want to express to be near. Use <WORD>poushoku</WORD> when you want to express to be near.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>tikuku</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahete</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>tikuku</WORD> and <WORD>ahete</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>tikuku</WORD> <DEFINITION>stoke</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ahete</WORD> <DEFINITION>to be close</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>tikuku</WORD> when you want to express stoke. Use <WORD>ahete</WORD> when you want to express to be close.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>tikuku</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ira thë hore hãimai ma kui, ira a hore tikukuprou tëhë, thoku ta thaprahe</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>while I keep the jaguar away (with my supernatural powers), while it stays at a respectful distance, (you can) take down the hammocks and leave</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>tikukuo</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>to stay away</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>ahete</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ya ahetetou tëhë ya rokema</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>when I was close I sat down</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahi</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahe</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ãhi</WORD> and <WORD>ahë</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ãhi</WORD> <DEFINITION>(name)</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ahë</WORD> <DEFINITION>(name)</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ãhi</WORD> when you want to express (name). Use <WORD>ahë</WORD> when you want to express (name).</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahe</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahi</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ahë</WORD> and <WORD>ãhi</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ahë</WORD> <DEFINITION>(name)</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ãhi</WORD> <DEFINITION>(name)</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ahë</WORD> when you want to express (name). Use <WORD>ãhi</WORD> when you want to express (name).</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahetepou</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahetepramai</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ahetepou</WORD> and <WORD>ahetepramai</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ahetepou</WORD> <DEFINITION>to keep close</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ahetepramai</WORD> <DEFINITION>to bring heavy or bulky objects close</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ahetepou</WORD> when you want to express to keep close. Use <WORD>ahetepramai</WORD> when you want to express to bring heavy or bulky objects close.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahetepramai</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahetepou</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ahetepramai</WORD> and <WORD>ahetepou</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ahetepramai</WORD> <DEFINITION>to bring heavy or bulky objects close</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ahetepou</WORD> <DEFINITION>to keep close</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ahetepramai</WORD> when you want to express to bring heavy or bulky objects close. Use <WORD>ahetepou</WORD> when you want to express to keep close.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahiai</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahiamai</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ãhiãi</WORD> and <WORD>ãhiãmai</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ãhiãi</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Intransitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to get muddy</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ãhiãmai</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Transitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to make muddy</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ãhiãi</WORD> when you want to express to get muddy. Use <WORD>ãhiãmai</WORD> when you want to express to make muddy.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ahiamai</WORD> instead of <WORD>ahiai</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ãhiãmai</WORD> and <WORD>ãhiãi</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ãhiãmai</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Transitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to make muddy</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ãhiãi</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Intransitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to get muddy</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ãhiãmai</WORD> when you want to express to make muddy. Use <WORD>ãhiãi</WORD> when you want to express to get muddy.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>ihu</WORD> instead of <WORD>titi</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ihu</WORD> and <WORD>titi</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ihu</WORD> <DEFINITION>niguas</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>titi</WORD> <DEFINITION>ant</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>ihu</WORD> when you want to express niguas. Use <WORD>titi</WORD> when you want to express ant.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>ihu</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ihu napë hayoyai</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>las niguas se desprenden (de los pies adonde están alojadas).</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>titi</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>thë mi titi</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>the night.</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>titi</WORD> instead of <WORD>ihu</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>titi</WORD> and <WORD>ihu</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>titi</WORD> <DEFINITION>ant</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ihu</WORD> <DEFINITION>niguas</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>titi</WORD> when you want to express ant. Use <WORD>ihu</WORD> when you want to express niguas.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>titi</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>thë mi titi</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>the night.</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>ihu</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ihu napë hayoyai</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>las niguas se desprenden (de los pies adonde están alojadas).</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>titi</WORD> instead of <WORD>ruwe</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>titi</WORD> and <WORD>ruwë</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>titi</WORD> is a <POS>Noun</POS> and <DEFINITION>ant</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ruwë</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Intransitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to be dark</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>titi</WORD> when you want to express ant. Use <WORD>ruwë</WORD> when you want to express to be dark.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>aiamo</WORD> instead of <WORD>aiamo hena(ki)</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ãiãmo</WORD> and <WORD>ãiãmo hena(ki)</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ãiãmo</WORD> <DEFINITION></DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ãiãmo hena(ki)</WORD> <DEFINITION></DEFINITION>.

Examples with <WORD>ãiãmo</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ãiãmori pë sherekapi si roo yaiokiri (cha.)</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>the arrow cane of the ãiãmo people is downriver</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>kirii hami wa wã wãri yaimopë, ihi namo wayu ha ãiãmoriwë a ta tarari</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>keep calling us cowards: this curare tip will make you see the ãiãmoriwë demon</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>aiamo hena(ki)</WORD> instead of <WORD>aiamo</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>ãiãmo hena(ki)</WORD> and <WORD>ãiãmo</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>ãiãmo hena(ki)</WORD> <DEFINITION></DEFINITION>, while <WORD>ãiãmo</WORD> <DEFINITION></DEFINITION>.

Examples with <WORD>ãiãmo</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ãiãmori pë sherekapi si roo yaiokiri (cha.)</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>the arrow cane of the ãiãmo people is downriver</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>aka hoprai</WORD> instead of <WORD>aka</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD> and <WORD>aka</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Transitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to scrape one</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>aka</WORD> is a <POS>Noun</POS> and <DEFINITION>tongue</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD> when you want to express to scrape one. Use <WORD>aka</WORD> when you want to express tongue.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>aka hõprai: rasparse la lengua con un bejuco (para retirar adherencias)</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>to scrape one's tongue with a vine (to remove residue).</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Examples with <WORD>aka</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>aka ha hõprarini a wã tetea pëa</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>what do his threats matter, he wastes his saliva in vain! (lit.: let him scrape his tongue to clean it, his threats do not matter)</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>aka hoprai</WORD> instead of <WORD>hoa</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD> and <WORD>hõã</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Transitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to scrape one</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>hõã</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Intransitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to be smoothed, swept, scraped, shaved</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD> when you want to express to scrape one. Use <WORD>hõã</WORD> when you want to express to be smoothed, swept, scraped, shaved.</USAGE>
<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>aka</WORD> instead of <WORD>aka hoprai</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>

When deciding between <WORD>aka</WORD> and <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD> in Yanomami:

1. <WORD>aka</WORD> is a <POS>Noun</POS> and <DEFINITION>tongue</DEFINITION>, while <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD> is a <POS>Verb (Transitive)</POS> and <DEFINITION>to scrape one</DEFINITION>.

<USAGE>Use <WORD>aka</WORD> when you want to express tongue. Use <WORD>aka hõprai</WORD> when you want to express to scrape one.</USAGE>

Examples with <WORD>aka</WORD>:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>aka ha hõprarini a wã tetea pëa</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>what do his threats matter, he wastes his saliva in vain! (lit.: let him scrape his tongue to clean it, his threats do not matter)</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>hetoshi: 1. Estar gastado, deshilachado, raído o dañado (una cuerda, un cordel, una correa). Se dice también de una fruta que ha perdido su envoltura después de una fricción. 2. Estar sucio de tierra (habla del sur del Orinoco.)</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>1. To be worn out, frayed, damaged (a rope, a cord, a strap). It is also said of a fruit that has lost its skin after friction. 2. To be dirty with earth (southern Orinoco speech).</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<QUERY>When should I use <WORD>hekura</WORD> instead of <WORD>kura</WORD> in Yanomami?</QUERY>
